titleStmt.title: Tamiḻneṟi Viḷakkam 17.
Experimenting with formatting for the final edition.

body.head: Commentary
body.p: e-tu. tōḻiyiṟ kūṭṭattup pakaṟ kuṟi yām āṟuṇarttutaṉutaliṟṟu.
The quoted [cūttiram] intends to make known the way in which the daytime meeting place for a union by means of the tōḻi occurs.
pāṅkiyai yuṇarntatu mutal ākak koṇṭu peyarntatīṟākac collap paṭṭaṉa vellān tōḻiyiṉ ākiya pakaṟ kuṟik kūṭṭam ām eṉṟa vāṟu.

All of the things mentioned, beginning with 'making known [his desire] to the tōḻi' and ending with '[the tōḻi] taking [the heroine] and departing', are the union at the daytime meeting-place on account of the tōḻi.

div.p: eṉpatu vēṟu pāṭu kaṇṭu pāṅki yaiyuṟṟatu.
eṉpatu kavarntu niṉṟa tōḻiyai mati yuṭaṉ paṭuppāṉ uṟṟut tōḻiyun talaimakaḷum uṭaṉ āya vaḻit talaimakaṉ viṉāyatu.

lg.l: yāṅkā kiyarōākiyarō is relatively common as a rhetorical question in Caṅkam Tamil, employing the optative. cf. KT40. In this case something like 'where will it fall?'. I am non quite sure why UVC felt the need to emend in this case. Perhaps he thought ākiyar was an epicene form and thus corrected it to the neuter singular, though would would be extremely surprising given his breadth of knowledge. vēntaṉiṉ ṉaruḷē

pūmeṉ ṟaṇṭaḻai koḷkuvaṉkoḷḷuvaṉ has no attestations, but can we hypothosise its existence as a participial noun formed in the same way as coḷḷuvāḷ? Both are mono-syllabic CVC verbal roots. For now I am favouring the known form. purintē
